snippet.title: Taylor lands medal on last day of world championships
snippet.content: SWIMMING: Taylor McKeown may not have finished amid the top few in her preferred event but the University of the Sunshine Coast swimmer will return from the world championships with a relay medal. The 22-year-old captured a bronze on the final day of competition on Monday, when she bolstered the Australian women's 4x100m medley relay team. She clocked 1min06.29sec for breaststroke, combining with Emily Seebohm, Emma McKeon and Bronte Campbell to record 3:54.29. The quartet finished behind United States (3:41.55) and Russia (3:53.38). It was a promising way to finish the meet for McKeown, who had earlier competed in the 100m and 200m breastroke events. In the latter, she qualified third fastest for the final before finishing seventh. But she'll return to the Sunshine Coast as a medal winner, alongside younger sister Kaylee, who was a revelation at her first major international competition. The 16-year-old was fourth in the 200m backstroke in 2:06.76 with a world junior record and she snared silver as a heat swimmer in the 4x100m mixed medley relay. "Can't believe my little sister just broke the junior world record and went 2.06 for her 200 backstroke," Taylor said via social media. "Such an amazing swim, finishing fourth and she only just turned 16....(she) has a bright future." Kaylee also received praise from the likes of Sunshine Coast's two-time Olympic gold medallist Melanie Wright. "Little legend. Well done superstar."
